Blood Glucose: Elevated levels (hyperglycemia), potentially leading to steroid-induced diabetes.
Liver Function Tests (ALT, AST, ALP, Bil: Elevated liver enzymes, though usually mild and reversible.
Complete Blood Count (CBC): Leukocytosis (elevated white blood cell count) due to demargination of neutrophils.
Electrolytes (Potassium, Sodium, Calcium: Hypokalemia (low potassium), hypernatremia (high sodium), and hypocalcemia (low calcium).
Lipid Profile (Cholesterol, Triglyceride: Elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels, increasing cardiovascular risk.
Bone Density (DEXA Scan): Decreased bone mineral density, indicating osteoporosis or osteopenia.
C-Reactive Protein (CRP): Decreased levels due to anti-inflammatory effects.
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR): Decreased levels due to suppression of inflammatory markers.
Adrenal Function Tests (ACTH, Cortisol): Suppressed ACTH and cortisol levels, indicating adrenal insufficiency with prolonged use.
Urinalysis: Glycosuria (glucose in urine) due to hyperglycemia.
Creatine Kinase (CK): Reduced levels due to muscle wasting or myopathy.
Parathyroid Hormone (PTH): Suppressed levels due to steroid-induced bone metabolism changes.
Serum Uric Acid: Elevated levels, potentially leading to gout in susceptible individuals.
White Blood Cell Differential: Neutrophilia (elevated neutrophils), with decreased eosinophils and lymphocytes.
Serum Albumin: Decreased levels in chronic use due to catabolic effects.
Immunoglobulin Levels (IgG, IgA, IgM): Reduced levels due to immunosuppressive effects.
Blood Pressure: Elevated (hypertension) due to fluid retention and vascular effects.
Bone Turnover Markers (Osteocalcin, CTX): Reduced levels, reflecting suppressed bone formation and increased resorption.
Urine Calcium Excretion: Increased levels, associated with risk of nephrolithiasis or osteoporosis.
